cdata.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 171, Number 54 (Tuesday, March 25, 2025)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. JAMES:H.R. 2328.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Pursuant to clause 7 of Rule XII of the Rules of the Houseof Representatives, the constitutional authority for Congressto enact this legislation is provided by:Article I, Section 8, Clause 3 of the United StatesConstitution, which grants Congress the power ``To regulateCommerce with foreign Nations, and among the several States,and with the Indian Tribes.'' The Soo Locks are a criticalcomponent of interstate and international commerce,facilitating the movement of goods essential to nationalsecurity and economic stability.Additionally, authority is derived from Article I, Section8, Clause 1, which provides Congress the power ``To providefor the common Defence and general Welfare of the UnitedStates.'' Ensuring the security and resilience of the SooLocks is vital to the defense industrial base and thenational security interests of the United States.Furthermore, Article I, Section 8, Clause 18, the Necessaryand Proper Clause, empowers Congress to enact legislationessential to carrying out its enumerated powers, includingthe regulation and protection of infrastructure critical tonational defense and economic security.[Page H1274]

Coast Guard and Maritime Transportation Subcommittee

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Coast Guard and Maritime Transportation.
Referred to the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure.

bill.title: Soo Locks Security and Economic Reporting Act of 2025

item.title: Soo Locks Security and Economic Reporting Act of 2025
Soo Locks Security and Economic Reporting Act of 2025
To study the security of the Soo Locks and effects on the supply chain resulting from a malfunction or failure of the Soo Locks, and for other purposes.

latestAction.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Coast Guard and Maritime Transportation.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
